questions.text: What are the following structures in the given image of axilla?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 1-Medial cord of brachial plexus, 2-long thoracic nerve, 3-subscapularis

Structure 1: Medial cord of brachial plexus
  • It is a part of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the upper limb.
  • The medial cord gives rise to multiple nerves responsible for innervating various muscles and structures in the upper limb.

Structure 2: Long thoracic nerve
  • It originates from the roots of the brachial plexus.
  • The long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle.
  • It plays a crucial role in stabilizing the scapula during movements of the upper limb.

Structure 3: Subscapularis
  • The subscapularis is one of the four muscles that form the rotator cuff in the shoulder region.
  • It is located on the anterior surface of the scapula (shoulder blade) and aids in the internal rotation of the arm.

questions.text: Where does the peripheral processes of spiral ganglion end?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: C
The peripheral processes of the spiral ganglion end in the organ of Corti, which is a sensory organ located in the cochlea. The organ of Corti contains hair cells, which are the sensory cells that respond to sound. The peripheral processes of the spiral ganglion synapse with the hair cells, and this is how the auditory nerve transmits sound information to the brain.
Other options :  
Option A is the  basilar membrane, which is a structure that supports the organ of Corti. Option B is the outer hair cells Option D is the vestibular membrane

questions.text: Which of the following is the endo-cochlear potential?
questions.solution:
Between endolymph and perilymph, there is a constant electrical potential of roughly +80–100 millivolts, with positivity inside the scala media and negative outside. This is known as the endocochlear potential, and it is produced by the stria vascularis' ongoing release of positive potassium ions into the scala media.

questions.text:
The cell counts in various Neubauer's chamber squares after charging with 20 times diluted blood are shown in the following picture. What is the total number of leukocytes?


1. 6000/mm3
2. 2400/mm3
3.  3000/mm3
4. 14200/mm3
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 6000/mm3

The method used here is called Total leukocyte counting (TLC) Principle of the TLC method:
  1. Blood is diluted with a fluid that causes the RBCs’ hemolysis, but WBCs remain intact, and then these are counted in the Neubauer chamber.
  2. Gentian violet lightly stains the leucocytes and allows those to be counted.
          Each of the square has a dimension of 1mm x lmm. Depth is 0.1 mm.
          Volume of one square = (1 x 1 x 0.1) mm3 = 0.1 mm3
          Concentration of cells = n/V x d
          (n= No. of cells, V= Volume of distribution, d= Dilution)
          Cells counted in 4 corner squares = n = (25 + 35 + 40 + 20) = 120
          Total Volume of 4 squares = 4 x 0.1 = 0.4 mm3
          Dilution factor = 20
          WbC Count = 120/0.4 x 20 = 6000 cells/mm3


Reference- https://www.emsdiasum.com/docs/technical/datasheet/68052-14

questions.text: Identify the control center for the stapedial reflex from following nerve roots.
questions.solution:
In response to high intensity sounds, the stapedius muscle supplied by the facial nerve tenses, helping in decreasing the vibrations reaching the middle ear, this is Stapedial Reflex.

Pathway - High intensity auditory stimulus reaches the cochleae, neural impulses from the auditory nerves ascend from both cochleae to each ipsilateral ventral cochlear nucleus (VCN), then from the VCN to the superior olivary complex (SOC) before the impulses cross at the brainstem to innervate both ipsilateral and contralateral facial motor nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase calcium absorption from the gut?
questions.solution:
Calcium ions absorption from the gut is reduced in alkaline medium. Ca2+ in alkaline media produces insoluble tricalcium phosphate, which interferes with its absorption. Alkaline pH is a better response in this situation even if phytates also reduce calcium absorption. Phytates also reduce calcium absorption but alkaline PH is a better answer.

Clinical Edge- Therefore, long-term taking Proton Pump Inhibitors can lead to osteoporosis due to decreased Ca++ absorption. 



Reference- https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/calcium-absorption

questions.text: In the gut, migratory motor complexes recur at intervals of:
questions.solution:
MMC (migrating motor complexes) is a pattern of electrical activity in the GI tract during a regular cycle of fasting. 
They tend to occur every 90 minutes. 
These motor complexes trigger peristalsis, which facilitates the transport of indigestible substances(bone/hair etc) from the stomach through the intestine past the sphincter (ileocolic) and into the colon. 

MMC is also known as Hunger Pangs, Broomstick or Housekeeper of GIT as they clear contents and prepares gut for next meal.
They are activated by Motilin produced by Mo Cells of stomach and duodenum.


To keep it simple regarding GIT movements-

Food - Peristalsis 
Faeces - Mass Movement 
While fasting- MMC
Vomiting - Reverse Peristalsis 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 486

questions.text: All of the following decreases in carbon monoxide's ability to diffuse except?
questions.solution:
The diffusion capacity of CO depends upon the alveolar surface area and thickness of the alveolar membrane.

Any factor which leads to decrease in the surface area will lead to decrease in the diffusion capacity.

  • Interstitial Lung Disease
  • Emphysema

Since, in case of polycythemia, more blood cells are available for CO uptake, its diffusion capacity increases.

questions.text: The potential created by freely diffusible ion flow across a semi-permeable membrane is determined using:
questions.solution:
The Nernst equation is used to determine the equilibrium potential of a permeable ion across a cell membrane at a specific concentration difference. The ion's unfettered passage across leaky channels causes the potential to develop.

E = -61.5 log Ci/Ce

Where, E = equilibrium potential (mV)

  Ci= intracellular concentration (mM)

  Ce= extracellular concentration (mM)

Other options:-

  • Gibbs equation takes consideration of non-diffusible ions also
  • Goldman equation takes consideration of all diffusible ions
  • Fick's principle measures the amount of blood flow from an organ 



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 9

questions.text: Why are CG islands in our DNA important?
questions.solution:
The cytosine nucleotide is followed by a guanine nucleotide at the CpG sites, also known as CG sites, in a linear sequence along the 5' 3' orientation of the DNA molecule.
CpG islands are genomic areas having a high frequency of CpG sites.

CpG dinucleotides' cytosines can be methylated to create 5-methylcytosines. A gene's expression can be altered by this methylation. 

Methylation results in silencing/decreasing the expression of the gene. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: What value is the pH of a solution with 5 millimole/liter of H+ ions closest to?

pH =-log[H+]

pH= -log[5*10^-3]

= -log(5) - log(l0^-3 )

= -log(l0/2) +3

= -1 + log2 +3

= 2 +0.3010

= 2.3 (approx)

[log 2 = 0.3010, log 10 = 1]

questions.text: What will be the Respiratory Quotient (RQ) of a person on pure carbohydrate diet?

RQ (Respiratory Quotient) is a ratio of the Volume of CO2 produced : Volume of O2 consumed.

Since, in case of Carbohydrate oxidation these two values turn out to be equal and hence, the value RQ tends to 1.

Normal Range of RQ = 0.7 to 1

questions.text: In the production of steroid hormones, a typical intermediary is:

questions.text: Select the option that is most effective for gluconeogenesis in starvation.
questions.solution:
“In gluconeogenesis, pyruvate carboxylase, which catalyzes the synthesis of oxaloacetate from pyruvate, requires acetylCoA as an allosteric activator. The presence of acetyl-CoA results in a change in the tertiary structure of the protein, lowering the Km value for bicarbonate. This means that as acetyl-CoA is formed from pyruvate, it automatically ensures the provision of oxaloacetate and, therefore, its further oxidation in the citric acid cycle. The activation of pyruvate carboxylase and the reciprocal inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase by acetyl-CoA derived from the oxidation of fatty acids explains the action of fatty acid oxidation in sparing the oxidation of pyruvate and in stimulating gluconeogenesis. The reciprocal relationship between these two enzymes in both liver and kidney alters the metabolic fate of pyruvate as the tissue changes from carbohydrate oxidation, via glycolysis, to gluconeogenesis during transition from a fed to a fasting state.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 184.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman had pallor, 9.5 mg/dL hemoglobin, MCV 100, and a 2 million/mm3 RBC count. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Folic acid deficiency

  • A high MCV here is suggestive of macrocytic anemia, as seen in a deficiency of folic acid.
  • The marrow is usually markedly hypercellular as a result of increased numbers of hematopoietic precursors. Megaloblastic changes are detected at all stages of erythroid development.
  • The most primitive cells (pro megaloblasts) are large, with a deeply basophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and a distinctive, fine nuclear chromatin pattern.
  • Defects in nuclear maturation, as seen in megaloblastic anemias due to folate or B12 deficiency, result in large oval erythrocytes (macro ovalocytes) with a normal hemoglobin content. The MCV and MCH are increased, while the MCHC remains normal. There is anisocytosis, and RDW is often increased.


*Audio Explanation: 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 654.

questions.text: The liver biopsy histology of a patient with hemochromatosis is provided below. Which stain from the list below was applied?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Prussian blue

* [Extra Edge]: Uses of Prussian blue stain
 
  • Hemochromatosis is a metabolic disorder which results in deposition of excess iron in the body in the form of hemosiderin. Tissues having iron deposition can then be stained with the help of Prussian Blue Stain. 
  • Intracellular ferritin is located in the cytosol and in lysosomes, in which partially degraded protein shells of ferritin aggregate into hemosiderin granules. Iron in hemosiderin is chemically reactive and turns blue-black when exposed to potassium ferrocyanide, which is the basis for the Prussian blue stain.


In Heriditary Haemochromatosis, the gene affected is HFE gene chromosome 6.
                                 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 655.

questions.text: Identify the most consistent feature of rapidly progressing glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crescent formation

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is characterized by a rapid decline in the GFR (GFR) of at least 50% over a short period. The main histopathologic finding is an extensive glomerular crescent formation.

* [Extra Edge]: Cresent Glomerulopathy
  • Depending on the underlying cause, the glomeruli often show focal and segmental necrosis, and variably show diffuse or focal endothelial proliferation, and mesangial proliferation.
  • Segmental glomerular necrosis and distinctive crescents adjacent to glomerular segments uninvolved by inflammatory or proliferative changes is the feature most typical of pauci-immune RPGN.
  • Crescents are formed by proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells and by migration of monocytes and macrophages into the urinary space.
  • Neutrophils and lymphocytes may be present. The crescents may obliterate the urinary space and compress the glomerular tuft. Fibrin strands are frequently prominent between the cellular layers in the crescents


Fig: Cresent Glomerulonephritis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 910.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a kidney transplant is suffering with decreased urine production. The microscopic image from a urinalysis is displayed below. Identify the structure that has an arrow on it:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hyaline casts

The structure marked in the above diagram is a Hyaline cast.

It appears to be a Waxy cast, but Hyaline cast is the best response because it develops from a hyaline cast.

* [Extra Edge]: Hyaline Casts

  • Normal: Up to 5 casts/low-power field
  • Associations: Normal finding in concentrated urine, fever, exercise, diuretics, pyelonephritis, chronic renal disease

questions.text: What speech impairment results from damage to the area of the brain shown in the micrograph below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Sensory aphasia
 
  • Sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia) is a type of aphasia that results from damage to the temporal lobe of the brain.
  • Damage to this area of the brain can disrupt the ability to understand language, both spoken and written.
  • People with sensory aphasia may have difficulty comprehending what others are saying, and they may also have difficulty finding the right words to express themselves.
  • The micrograph shows the temporal lobe of the brain, and the area that is damaged is Wernicke's area.






Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1462e.162,533,529

questions.text: The heart of a patient whose death was presumed to be from a myocardial infarction was stained with triphenyl tetrazolium tetrachloride dye at autopsy. What shade will the myocardium be that is still viable?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Red

  • It is possible to highlight the area of necrosis by immersion of tissue slices in a solution of triphenyl tetrazolium chloride.
  • This gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, Non infarcted myocardium with preserved lactate dehydrogenase activity.
  • This is Because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.
* Audio Explanation:
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 548.

questions.text: The resolving power of a microscope does not depend upon which of the following :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thickness of the film

The resolving power of a microscope refers to its ability to distinguish between two closely spaced objects as separate entities.
  • The resolving power is influenced by the numerical aperture of the objective lens, the wavelength of the light source used, and the size of the aperture in the condenser.
  • The resolving power depends on several factors, but it does not depend on the thickness of the film or specimen being observed.
  • The focal length of the eyepiece affects the magnification but not the resolving power.
Though focal length of eyepiece is also an answer, thickness of the film can be more appropriate and best answer.  

Online Reference:
Mualla F, Aubreville M, Maier A. Microscopy. 2018 Aug 3. In: Maier A, Steidl S, Christlein V, et al., editors. Medical Imaging Systems: An Introductory Guide [Internet]. Cham (CH): Springer; 2018. Chapter 5. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546149/ doi: 10.1007/978-3-319-96520-8_5

questions.text: Where are MHC antigens absent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Erythrocyte

MHC antigens are absent on erythrocytes. 

  • HLA class I antigens (A, B and C) are found on the surface of virtually all nucleated cells and platelets. They are the principal antigens involved in graft rejection and cell-mediated cytolysis.
  • HLA class II antigens are more restricted in distribution, being found only on cells of the immune system- macrophages, dendritic cells, activated T cells, and particularly on B cell
*Audio Explanation:
 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 198.

questions.text: Which stain is useful for identifying premalignant lesions of the lip?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Toluidine Blue

Toluidine Blue dye is used to identify premalignant lesions of the lip because it being a basic metachromatic dye, stains the excessive nuclear material present in malignant lesions, but not that of normal mucosa and can thus aid in the differentiation.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1152.

questions.text: Three medicines were the subject of a pharmacological experiment to determine how they affected blood pressure and heart rate. The graphs below were acquired before and after the medication was administered. Which of the subsequent claims is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 2: B is epinephrine
 
  • At higher concentrations of adrenaline, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen.
  • Therefore an increase in BP is seen with IV administration of adrenaline.
  • Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the β2 action predominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen.
  • This is referred to as the biphasic reaction. 
* [Extra Edge]: Anti cholinergic drugs




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

C is a noncompetitive antagonist as it shows less efficacy than A and B.

questions.text: An uninjured volunteer was taken for a blood test.   • Increased BT is suggestive of deficiency of clotting factors.

questions.text: Select the drug that can be used in benzodiazepine toxicity.

questions.text: Select the drug that can be given in renal failure safely.
questions.solution:

Linagliptin is primarily excreted via feces and to doesn't require any dose modification in renal failure. 
All the rest of the DPP-4 inhibitors require dose modification if GFR falls below 50ml.min.1.73m2

choices.text: Research papers and other articles proving the efficacy of the drug

questions.text: Each medication formulation must include a drug advertisement letter that provides numerous details regarding the drug, such as dosage, frequency, and half-life. Which of the following details does the medication advertisement letter not need to include?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is (Option 1) Research papers and other articles proving the efficacy of the drug

The medication advertisement letter does not need to include research papers and other articles proving the efficacy of the drug. This is because the efficacy of the drug has already been proven through clinical trials and is approved by the FDA/CDSCO

* The medication advertisement letter should include the following details:

  • Dosage: The recommended dosage of the drug, as well as any dosing adjustments that may be necessary for certain populations (e.g., children, elderly, pregnant women).
  • Frequency: How often the drug should be taken.
  • Half-life: The amount of time it takes for the body to eliminate half of the drug.
  • Adverse effects: Any potential side effects of the drug, including both common and rare side effects.
  • Precautions: Any special instructions or warnings that patients should be aware of before taking the drug.
  • Storage instructions: How the drug should be stored to ensure its potency.
  • Call to action: A statement that encourages patients to talk to their doctor about whether or not the drug is right for them.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 93.

choices.text: Postauricular skin > scalp > scrotum > dorsal aspect of hand > sole

questions.text: Select the option that correctly represents the sequence of the rate of topical drug absorption.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Postauricular skin > scrotum > scalp > dorsal aspect of hand >sole

*Factors that affect the absorption of drugs through the skin:
  • 1. Concentration
  • 2. The molecular weight of the molecule
  • 3. Duration of contact
  • 4. Solubility of medication
  • 5. Physical condition of the skin
  • 6. Part of the body exposed including the amount of hair on the skin.

In general, the rate of absorption of chemicals through the skin follows the following scheme:

Postauricular skin > Scrotal > Armpit= Scalp > Back = Abdomen > Palm= under the surface of the foot.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Identify the site that is least commonly preferred for insulin injection.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) dorsum of hand

* [ Extra Edge]Sites of insulin injection:
  • The four safe areas for insulin injections are the sides of the thighs, the backs of the upper arms, the abdomen and the upper outer buttocks.
  • To avoid bumps and scar tissue on the skin, rotation of insulin injection sites should be done and a systematic approach to injection site rotation adopted.
  • Thus, injections may be given in the abdomen, outer thigh, back of the arm, and flank/buttocks regions.
  • Insulin injected on the abdomen acts faster than insulin injected on the thigh.
  • The rate of absorption of insulin injected on the arm is between that of insulin injected on the abdomen and that injected on the thigh.

Fig: Insulin Injection sites

Bahendeka S, Kaushik R, Swai AB, Otieno F, Bajaj S, Kalra S, Bavuma CM, Karigire C. EADSG Guidelines: Insulin Storage and Optimisation of Injection Technique in Diabetes Management. questions.text: Select the statement that is not true about rifabutin as compared to rifampicin.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rifabutin is more efficacious for pulmonary TB as compared to rifampicin

Rifabutin is more effective than Rifampicin against Mycobacterium avium but not against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

All of the other statements are true in case of Rifabutin.

Characteristic Rifabutin Rifampicin
Indications - TB (Tuberculosis)- MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex) - TB (Tuberculosis)- Leprosy- Meningococcal carriers
Drug Interactions Fewer interactions with other drugs compared to Rifampicin Strong enzyme inducer (CYP450), many drug interactions
Side Effects - Less hepatotoxicity- Uveitis (eye inflammation) - Hepatotoxicity- Orange-red discoloration of body fluids
Half-Life Longer half-life than Rifampicin Shorter half-life than Rifabutin
Usage Often used in HIV patients or those on ART due to fewer interactions Typically used in standard TB treatment regimens
Dosage Lower dosage compared to Rifampicin Higher dosage required compared to Rifabutin
Effectiveness More effective against MAC than Rifampicin More effective against TB than Rifabutin
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 822.

questions.text: Identify the drug that does not have a role in osteoporosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Milnacipran
 
  • All of the given options except Milnapricin are used in managing Osteoporosis.
  • Milnacipran is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It is not used in treating Osteoporosis. It is used in the management of Fibromyalgia.
  • PTH and strontium can be used in treating osteoporosis in some cases.
  • denosumab is anti-RANK ligand monoclonal antibody used in osteoporosis.
Treatment of Osteoporosis
Class Examples Mechanism of Action
Bisphosphonates - Alendronate- Risedronate- Zoledronic acid Inhibit bone resorption, increasing bone density.
SERMs (Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators) - Raloxifene Mimic estrogen to protect bones, reduce resorption.
PTH Analogues - Teriparatide- Abaloparatide Stimulate bone formation.
RANK Ligand Inhibitors - Denosumab Inhibit bone resorption by blocking RANKL.
Calcitonin - Calcitonin (salmon) Inhibit bone resorption.
Strontium Ranelate - Strontium ranelate Increases bone formation and reduces resorption.
Estrogen Therapy - Conjugated estrogens Increase bone density by reducing resorption.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 345.

questions.text: Which of these drugs does not cause pigmentation of nail?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Amiodarone
 
  • All of the given options cause nail pigmentation except Amiodarone.
  • Amiodarone can cause corneal deposits but doesn't cause nail pigmentation.  Amiodarone also can cause skin hyper pigmentation. Skin hyperpigmentation is another important adverse effect, affecting 4–9% of patients taking amiodarone.
  • long-term therapy with amiodarone leads to characteristic blue-grey discolorations, located mostly on the face, ears, and palms of the hands.

* Nail pigmentation causing drugs:

  • Phenothiazines like chlorpromazine
  • Chloroquine
  • Minocycline
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 578.

choices.text: To adjust maintenance dose of digoxin required to keep the blood levels within therapeutic range
Intravenous administration in emergency and urgent dosing
It requires a high loading dose to be administered

questions.text: Digoxin has a 36-hour half-life and is derived from a plant product. How can this information aid in the creation of a treatment plan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) To adjust maintenance dose of digoxin required to keep the blood levels within therapeutic range 

 
The given half-life determines the daily maintenance dosing to maintain therapeutic plasma levels.
 
  • The half-life of digoxin is 36 to 48 hours in patients with normal renal function and 3.5 to 5 days in anuric patients.
  • In patients with normal renal function, an oral daily maintenance dose without a loading dose results in a steady-state blood concentration in approximately 7 days.
  • Hence, the daily maintenance dose is decided based on the half-life of the drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 559.

questions.text: Identify the bacteria seen in the following gram stained specimen.
questions.solution:
In the given image, Cocci are depicted in pink colour, suggesting they are gram -ve.

Only gram -ve cocci in the options : N. Gonorrhoeae

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae are lanceolate gram positive cocci in pairs.
  • Staphylococcus aureus are gram positive cocci found in grape-like clusters..
  • Haemophilus influenzae are gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli.
The given slide shows gram negative diplococci within the polymorphs, characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. It is non-sporulating, non-motile diplococcus that is aerobic but may grow anaerobically also. It is oxidase and catalase positive. It shows twitching motility. It is flagella independent form of bacteria translocation over moist surfaces that occurs by the extension and retraction of polar type 4 pili. These pili act as virulence factors by promoting attachment to host cells and inhibiting phagocytosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 230.

questions.text: Why are schizonts and late trophozoite stages of plasmodium falciparum not seen in peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
Schizont and late trophozoite stages of Plasmodium falciparum not seen in peripheral blood smear because falciparum shows the property of CytoAdherence.

After the parasite infects RBCs it causes protrusion of ‘knobs’ on the surface of RBC which cause it to cling on to the capillary endothelium and stick to it.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most typical systemic symptom experienced by larval Helminths such Ancylostoma, Strongyloides, and Ascaris during migration?

questions.text: A patient with benign prostate enlargement was hospitalised for three weeks. He soon suffered what was likely a urinary tract infection related to his catheter. questions.text: A patient with acute hydrophobia is brought to the hospital. You took corneal scrapings from the patient and suspect rabies. What test should be performed on this sample to determine whether rabies is present?
questions.solution:
To determine whether rabies is present in corneal scrapings, the most appropriate test to perform is 4. Direct immunofluorescence.

This test allows for the detection of rabies virus antigens in the sample, providing a rapid and specific diagnosis of rabies. Negri bodies are typically identified in brain tissue rather than corneal scrapings, and while RT-PCR can be used, direct immunofluorescence is more commonly employed for clinical samples in suspected rabies cases.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient with altered sensorium is taken to the emergency room. An urgent neurosurgery procedure was required after a non-contrast CT indicated hydrocephalus. The patient was alone and didn't have any identification with them. Which of the following provisions of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) permits the neurosurgeon to carry out the treatment without a guardian's informed consent?
questions.solution:
In the given case Section 92 of IPC is applicable because the intervention was done by the doctor in good faith and as it was not possible to obtain consent form the patient.
  • Section 87 IPC: A person above 18 years of age can give consent to suffer any harm if the act is not intended and not known to cause death or grievous hurt.
  • Section 89 IPC: A child under 12 years of age or a person of unsound mind cannot give consent to suffer any harm for an act which may cause grievous hurt or death even if done in good faith, but the consent has to be obtained from the guardian of the child or a sane person.
  • Section 90 IPC: Consent given by an insane person or given under fear of injury, death etc. or due to misconception of a fact is invalid.
  • Section 92 IPC: Any harm caused to a person in good faith even without the person's consent is not an offence if the circumstances were such that it was impossible to obtain consent of the person or his lawful guardian at that material time for that thing to be done for the benefit of the person. However the act should not extend to intentionally causing hurt other than for preventing death, grievous hurt or curing of disease or infirmity.
  • If a patient is unconscious and there is imminent danger to his life and there is no designated person to give a consent then acc. To S. 92 IPC the law presumes that consent has been deemed to be given (can be an example of Implied Consent). If the emergency treatment is no longer required or patient is fit to give consent or a guardian/relative is present then doctrine of implied consent do not govern.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 53.

questions.text: The following patient was brought in for an autopsy. What is cause of discolouration in in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hematoma formation
 
  • Image given is mostly suggestive of hematoma formation. 
  • If the bleeding is small and thin-layered, it is called haemorrhage. If it is large and space- occupying, it is called haematoma.
  • The application of a moderate force to the head may cause a severe intracranial haemorrhage, while a greater force may not produce haemorrhage. Injuries to the meninges may cause extradural, subdural or subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: The same needle that was used on a patient who had HIV was also used on another patient. The latter patient is confirmed to have HIV infection, according to tests. Which part of the Indian penal code penalises the doctor for this negligence?
questions.solution:
The doctor here has done a negligent ad which has caused HIV to a patient. This is punishable under Section 269 of IPC.

+ Section 269 : Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life

Whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six month, or with fine, or with both.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 55.

questions.text: Which of these is not suggestive of domestic violence in a child?
questions.solution:
* Audio Explanation: 

Wormian bones are small bones present in between sutures. Sometimes they occur normally and also Osteogenesis imperfecta causes Wormian Bones, not child abuse. The complex of non-accidental injuries sustained by infants and young children as a result of abuse is referred to by a number of names, including battered child syndrome, shaken infant syndrome, stress-related infant abuse, and non-accidental trauma.

The diagnostic triad consists of subdural hematomas, multiple long bone fractures, and retinal haemorrhage .

questions.text:
Police discovered and brought a deceased male foetus that had been abandoned for autopsy. "The head to feet length is
63 cm, eyes are open, pupillary membrane is absent, Crown Rump Length is 23 cm, testes are at the superficial inguinal ring, and the weight of the foetus is 1000 gm," was the report. What is the fetus's approximate age?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. 7 months

Hess’ rule can be used to calculate the age of the fetus:


Crown-Rump length, CRL=*CHL (Crown Heel length)

Hence, CHL = 3/2 CRL

So, Here CHL = 3/2 x 23 = 34.5 = 35 cm approx.

Now Applying Hess's rule, 

Age = 35/5 = 7 months

Also, the pupillary membrane also disappears at 7 months.

The testes reach the level of superficial inguinal at 7 months as well.

Hence, the age of the fetus is 7 months.
 

Reference: Parikh's Textbook of Medical Jurisprudence, Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Page No 438.

questions.text: A woman who had consumed an unknown poison now for about 12 hours was taken from the village unconscious. Her blood pressure was 90/50 mm Hg, her heart rate was 103/min, and her breathing rate was 19/min. Her breath had a kerosene-like odour. Which of the following should be avoided in her management?
questions.solution:
The signs and symptoms are suggestive of Organophosphorous poisoning.
Antidote of choice is Atropine. Immediate airway management is done if required. Vasopressors can be given.
Gastric lavage is most useful if done withing 1 hour of ingestion and can be done up to 2 to 4 hours of ingestion. It is less useful after 2 hours of ingestion, non-fatal dose ingestion, and if patient vomited after ingestion of poison.

questions.text: A marker for ovarian cancer screening is CA-125. Histopathological confirmation of ovarian cancer was performed in a cohort of patients in order to characterise this test. 20/100 of the women who tested negative for this test had ovarian cancer, compared to 60/100 of the women who tested positive. What is the test's negative predictive value?
questions.solution:
Negative predictive value is defined as - 
  • The proportion of negative results that are true negatives, that is, the likelihood that a person with a negative result truly does not have the disease.
  • NPV =(number who test negative and do not have them disease= TN)/( total =  number who test negative =TN+ FN)


In the question,
  • Now, total number of negative cases = True Negative + False Negative Cases
  • True negatives= 80
  • Total negatives= 100
  • Negative predictive value= 80/100 = 80%


Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 76.

questions.text: The impact of pulse oximeter readings in neonates with and without micropore was examined in a study. As seen in the picture, a plot was created between the two values. Which of the following statements about the figure's conclusions is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: There is positive correlation between two groups

The given diagram describes a SCATTER PLOT.

CORRELATION COEFFICIENT :-
  • r – The value is always less than 1
  • Negative or positive correlation is depicted by the slope of the graph.
  • Negative slope – Negative correlation
  • Positive slope – Positive correlation
  • Straight line- No correlation

In the given figure, it is a positive slope and moreover the plots are more or less around the line depicting a strong positive correlation.
The strength of correlation depends on how much the plots are away from the line.

questions.text: The number of lymph nodes that tested positive in a group of breast cancer patients who had axillary dissection was the subject of a study. The quantity and frequency of positive nodes were displayed on the graph shown below. Which of the following statements is true?

The direction of the tail, or the direction of the values with the least frequency, designates whether a set of data is positive or negative skewed.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best for figuring out the limit for a test's positive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ROC is used to evaluate the test's sensitivity and specificity.
  • The probability ratio, which is crucial for establishing the test's threshold, is found using the tangent to the curve.
  • The specificity diminishes with increasing sensitivity.
  • The tangent of the curve aids in determining the test's accuracy criterion, which is high sensitivity without sacrificing specificity.
Each point on the ROC curve represents a sensitivity/specificity pair corresponding to a particular cutoff point or decision threshold.
A test that discriminates perfectly between the presence and absence of disease would have an ROC curve that passes through the upper left corner (100% sensitivity, 100% specificity)—so the closer the curve is to the upper left corner, the higher the overall accuracy of the test. A completely random test (e.g., coin tossing) would give an ROC “curve” that is actually the red line.

The shape of the curve therefore reflects the quality of the test; the better the test, the more the curve moves to the upper left. This can be quantified in terms of the area under the curve (AUC); the worst case is 0.5 (the red line), and the best is 1.00 (upper left-hand corner). A “good” test is one with a high rate of true positives and a low rate of false negatives over a reasonable range of cutoff values; in other words it has a high AUC as the curve moves towards the upper left corner.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 74.

questions.text: To determine the average blood pressure in each town, a study was conducted in three states. Each home in the three villages was visited by the health workers who were assigned to the area. Each community's average blood pressure was determined and compared. What kind of research methodology is this an example of?
questions.solution:
The study given in the question is Cross sectional study.

Cross Sectional Study :
  • An observational study method which examines cross-sectional data, which is information gathered from a population or a representative subset at a particular point in time.
  • Cross-sectional studies are more useful for chronic than short-lived diseases.
  • For example, in a study of hypertension, we can also collect data during the survey about age, sex, physical exercise, body weight, salt intake and other variables of interest. Then we can determine how prevention of hypertension is related to certain variables simultaneously measured.
  • Such a study tells us about the distribution of a disease in population rather than its etiology.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 84.

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady from a dry state who had consumed rye for an extended period of time complained of exhaustion, nausea, and weakness in both lower limbs. She eventually loses the ability to walk altogether. What is the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
• The reason for developing this illness is consuming Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal), which contains the ODAP/BOAA toxin.
  • It produces pyramidal tract injury, which manifests as paralysis with evidence of higher motor neuron damage in the lower limbs and a lack of strength in or inability to move those limbs.
  • Ingestion of legumes containing the toxin occurs despite an awareness of the means to detoxify Lathyrus.
  • Drought conditions can lead to shortages of both fuel and water, preventing the necessary detoxification steps from being taken, particularly in impoverished countries.
  • When certain legumes from the genus Lathyrus are consumed, it can lead to a neurological disorder known as neurolathyrism in humans.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page no 759.

questions.text: To determine the average intraocular pressure, a study was done. IOP was measured in 400 individuals, with a mean value of 25 mm Hg and an SD of 10 mm Hg. What would be the range of IOP for 95% of the population?
questions.solution:
The LL and UL estimates for the Statistic are given as: 

Lower limit: Statistic - C*SE (statistic)

Upper limit: Statistic + C*SE (statistic) 

Standard error, SE= {standard deviation/√ n)}

  n = sample size

 

C= Confidence coefficient

1.96 for 95% confidence interval

Hence, in this question,

N = 400 

SD = 10

=>SE =0.5

Mean statistic = 25 mm Hg

Now for 95% confidence interval, C = 2 approximately 

95% CI= 25 - 2*0.5 to 25 + 2*0.5 = 24-26 mm  Hg.

Hence, 95% CI of IOP will be 24 to 26 mm Hg.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 21, 22, 23.

RR = incidence in exposed/incidence in non-exposed

The interpretation of RR is done as follows:

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient reports postural changes along with dyspnea and a productive cough. The patient had smoked for 20 pack-years in the past. Additionally, the patient has a recent history of binge drinking. The chest X-ray is displayed below. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Clinical features with history of smoking & binge drinking (increases risk of aspiration) and chest X-ray findings showing cavitation & necrosis are suggestive of lung abscess.

Most common cause of primary lung abscess is anaerobes. So, Next step in management is Intravenous clindamycin and fluids.
 
  • Primary lung abscesses is thought to originate when chiefly anaerobic bacteria (as well as microaerophilic streptococci) in the gingival crevices are aspirated into the lung parenchyma in a susceptible host.
  • Thus, patients who develop primary lung abscesses usually carry an overwhelming burden of aspirated material or are unable to clear the bacterial load.
  • Pneumonitis develops initially (exacerbated in part by tissue damage caused by gastric acid); then, over a period of 7–14 days, the anaerobic bacteria produce parenchymal necrosis and cavitation whose extent depends on the host–pathogen interaction. Anaerobes are thought to produce more extensive tissue necrosis in polymicrobial infections in which virulence factors of the various bacteria can act synergistically to cause more significant tissue destruction.

For primary lung abscesses, the recommended regimens are:

(1) Clindamycin (600 mg IV three times daily; then, with the disappearance of fever and clinical improvement, 300 mg PO four times daily) or
(2) an IV-administered β-lactam/β- lactamase combination, followed—once the patient’s condition is stable—by orally administered amoxicillin-clavulanate. 

This therapy should be continued until imaging demonstrates that the lung abscess has cleared or regressed to a small scar. Treatment duration may range from 3–4 weeks to as long as 14 weeks



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1020-1022.

questions.text: Determine the diagnosis based on the ECG below:

  • It develops when every other P wave is NOT followed by a QRS complex because the P wave is not passed by the AV node to reach the ventricles.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient complains of right-sided palatal paralysis and loss of sensation on face. Horner's syndrome, nystagmus, vertigo, ataxia, and dysphagia are discovered during examination. The patient is unable to stand on his own two feet. What causes this manifestation the most frequently?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms are compliant with a case of Lateral Medullary Syndrome, most common cause of which is the occlusion of Vertebral artery > posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

 

Symptoms of Lateral Medullary Syndrome:

  • Contralateral sensory deficits from the body
  • Ipsilateral Cerebellar signs like Ataxia
  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face
  • Ipsilateral palatal, pharyngeal and laryngeal hemiparesis.
  • Ipsilateral Horner Syndrome.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3329.

questions.text:
A condition known as hypereosinophilic syndrome involves the heart, neurological system, or bone marrow and is defined by an increased eosinophil count in the blood for at least six months without any apparent explanation. What eosinophil count is required for diagnosis?
1. >500/mm3
2. >1000/ mm3
3. >1500/ mm3
4. >2000/ mm3
questions.solution:
Diagnostic criteria for hypereosinophilic syndrome:
  • Persistent eosinophilia > 1500/cu mm
  • Increased marrow eosinophils
  • Myeloblasts <20% in blood or marrow.

Other similar conditions must be excluded before concluding diagnosis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 864.

questions.text: A patient has a three-day history of vomiting. Upon investigation, dehydration was discovered. After additional testing, it was discovered that the patient had elevated creatinine, a pH of 7.22, a pCO2 of 24 mm Hg, an HCO3 of 9 mEq, a Na+ of 138 mEq/L, and a K+ of 3.4 mEq/L. Decide which acid-base imbalance this patient has:
questions.solution:
On examining the values it appears to be a case of Metabolic acidosis
  • pH decreased (Normal= 7.35-7.45) = Acidosis
  • Normal=40–45 mm Hg. Here, pCO2 dropped. A lower pCO2 will attempt to raise pH. The mechanism must thus be a secondary compensatory one.
 
  • According to compensation formula for Metabolic alkalosis, Paco2 = [HCO3–] + 15.
  • Here in this question, PaCO2 value should be 9+15 = 24 (22-26) +- 2. It signifies there is full respiratory compensation.
  • Therefore, it is a case of Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.
 

As a result, the main factor contributing to the Acid-Base imbalance must be a drop in serum bicarbonate levels, or metabolic acidosis.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same
 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: Determine the base deficit in a patient weighing 75 kg with a pH of 6.96, a pCO2 of 30, and an HCO3-- level of 6 mEq/L:
questions.solution:
The base deficit in the patient turns out to be around 500 mEq.

It can be calculated using:

Total bicarbonate deficit= 0.3 x weight (kg) x base deficit (Standard Base deficit)

Base deficit= 0.4 x Weight (in Kg) x [24- (Sr. bicarbonate)]

Here, BE= 0.4 x 75 x [24-6] = 540 m.eq which is approximately near 500 m.eq



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 360.

questions.text:
Which is the incorrect match about anti-epileptic drugs ?
1st line drugs Second line drugs
Focal seizure Lamotrigine, CBZ, Phenytoin Valproate
Absence seizure CBZ Ethosuximide, Valproate
Myoclonic seizure  valproate, Lamotrigine Clonazepam
GTCS Valproate, Lamotrigine, Topiramate Phenytoin, CBZ
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 2

The first line drug in Absence seizure is Ethosuximide.
Lamotrigine, Clonazepam, Zonisamide and Levetiracetam can be used as second line Drugs.
Thus option 2 is the incorrect match.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 443.

questions.text: You are to begin the treatment of an 80 kg male patient with an inotrope at a dose of 10 mcg/kg/min after he reported to the emergency room with hypotension. 200 mg of the medication are present in each 5 mL amp. You decide to produce a 250 mL solution using the medication from 2 ampules combined with saline. Given that 16 drops equal 1 mL, what should the drug solution flow rate be to maintain the patient's blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 8 drops/min

A dosing of 10 microgram/kg/min of the drug is required 

Weight = 80 kg

Total dose required= 10*80 = 800 mcg/min = 0.8 mg/min

Now,
two 5 mL vials each containing 200 mg are diluted to a 250 mL solution 

i.e. 400 mg is mixed in 250 mL

 

Concentration of solution: 1 mL = 400/250 mg = 8/5 = 1.6 mg/mL 

Now, 1 mL = 16 drops= 1.6 mg

i.e. 16 drops contain 1.6 mg

Hence, 0.8 mg/min= 8 drops/min= 0.5 mL/min
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 24.

choices.text: Change atenolol and thiazide to calcium channel blocker and ACE inhibitor and add bisacodyl for constipation
Change imipramine and haloperidol to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation
Only add bisacodyl for constipation and continue rest of the medications

questions.text: A 86-year-old woman arrived at the clinic with acute constipation. She had been taking medicine for five years as a recognised hypertension. Her blood pressure was  157/98 mm Hg in the clinic. A supine blood pressure reading revealed a reading of 90/60 mm Hg. She has just experienced depression. She is taking docusate, imipramine, haloperidol, atenolol, thiazide as medications. What is the management's best course of action going forward?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Change imipramine and haloperidol to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation

Considering the symptoms given in the problem, imipramine and haloperidol must be changed to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation.
 
  • This patient's postural hypotension is most likely caused by imipramine's alpha blocking and its interactions with thiazides.
  • She also has Imipramine's anticholinergic side effects (constipation). Imipramine, a TCA, must thus be stopped, and Fluoxetine, an SSRI, together with a laxative to treat any existing constipation, should be begun.  
  • Additionally, because Haloperidol and other conventional antipsychotics have anticholinergic adverse effects, she should begin taking the atypical antipsychotic Risperidone(with lesser anticholinergic side effects).
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 485.

questions.text:
A male patient, 42 years old, has jaundice. His ALT was 51 U, AST 48 U, ALP and GGTP were all within normal range. The liver's ultrasound suggested cirrhosis. Following the use of viral markers, the results were as follows. 
Test Result
Anti-HAV Negative
Anti-HBsAg Negative
Anti-HBeAg Negative
Anti-HBcAg lgG Positive
Anti-HBcAg lgM Negative
HBsAg Negative
Anti-HCV Positive
Anti-HEV Negative

What is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Both the anti-HCV and anti-HBcAg IgG antibodies in this patient are positive.

Anti-HBcAg IgG positive in this case is only a sign of prior Hepatitis-B infection. Anti-HCV antibodies indicate the presence of a hepatitis-C infection.

In order to establish a diagnosis of Chronic Hepatitis-C prior to beginning Interferon therapy, HCV-RNA levels should be assessed by RT-PCR.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 553.

questions.text: Police took a 25-year-old unidentified individual from the roadside who was vomiting, disoriented, and experiencing altered senses to the hospital department. His BP was 90/70 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, body temperature was -36.4°C, and breathing rate was 11/min. He had bilateral pin-point pupils when examined. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Opioid poisoning.

The classical presentation of miosis with respiratory depression is suggestive of opioid poisoning.

Opioids cause physical dependence. Its effects are as follows:
  • Miosis
  • Orthostatic hypotension 
  • Respiratory depression 
  • Stupor
  • Coma
  • Antidote – Naloxone
The classical triad of acute opioid poisoning is pin point pupil, respiratory depression and altered sensorium.

Option 1: The clinical signs of pontine hemorrhage are:
Respiratory disturbances and failure
  • Tetraplegia
  • decerebrate posture
  • hyperthermia
  • pinpoint pupils

Option 2: Features of miosis and respiratory depression are less likely in an independent case of hypothermia.

Option 4: Dhatura poisoning patient will present with
  • Fever
  • Altered mental status
  • Dilated pupils
  • Dry skin and mucosa
* Treatment:  physostigmine 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 586.

questions.text: Continuous murmur cannot be heard in:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. VSD with aortic regurgitation
 
  • A continuous murmur is predicated on a pressure gradient that persists between two cardiac chambers or blood vessels across systole and diastole. The murmurs typically begin in systole, envelop the second heart sound (S2), and continue through some portion of diastole.
 
  • The classic example of a continuous murmur is that associated with a PDA, which usually is heard in the second or third interspace at a slight distance from the sternal border.
 
  • Other causes of a continuous murmur include a ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm with creation of an aortic–right atrial or right ventricular fistula, a coronary or great vessel arteriovenous fistula, and an arteriovenous fistula constructed to provide dialysis access.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1822.

questions.text: Inhalers with a metering system are used to treat asthma. It is advised that you shake the MDI thoroughly before using it, exhale, bring the inhaler to your mouth, start to breathe in slowly, press the top of the inhaler once, and keep breathing in slowly until you have taken a full breath. After that, hold your breath for 10 seconds. A second MDI puff may be necessary for some patients to experience symptomatic relief. Which one of the following directions for using the MDI again is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Wait for 1 minute between two puffs

It is recommended to wait for 15-30 seconds between 2 puffs.

Other options: -

  • MDI should be shaken well so that particles that are settled down also form uniform concentration.
  • Mouth should be rinsed to prevent oral mucocutaneous candidiasis.
  • Inhaler should be cleaned before use as it is exposed to oral mucosa.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 83.

choices.text: Administer a small diluted dose first prior to infusion to look for any allergy to iron preparation

questions.text: Select the option that is not true regarding iron supplementation in iron deficiency anemia.
A patient with altered sensorium arrives at the emergency room. The test that could be done at last is:
questions.solution:
• For patients with altered sensorium, it is generally recommended that an imaging study be performed prior to lumbar puncture to exclude the causes of raised ICP (large intracranial mass lesion) and to prevent herniation. “Lumbar puncture is performed less frequently  for coma diagnosis because neuroimaging effectively excludes intracerebral & extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage. 
 
  • The metabolic aberrations commonly encountered in clinical practice are usually revealed by measurement of electrolytes, glucose, calcium, magnesium, osmolarity, and renal (blood urea nitrogen) and hepatic (NH3) function.
 
  • Lumbar puncture should be performed if no cause is readily apparent, as examination of the CSF remains indispensable in the diagnosis of various forms of meningitis and encephalitis.


NOTE: An imaging study should be performed prior to lumbar puncture to exclude a large intracranial mass lesion, which could lead to herniation with lumbar puncture.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 187.

questions.text: A patient with lung cancer had a 16.4 mmol/L serum calcium level when they were first seen. What will be the initial management action be?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. IV fluids and furosemide

I.V. fluids and diuretics are the first-line treatments for managing hypercalcemia in an emergency.

Even though IV bisphosphonates are the preferred medication for treating malignant hypercalcemia, their activity doesn't begin for at least 3–4 days, thus they are useless in an urgent situation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3173, 3183.

In TRALI (Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury), symptoms tend to resolve within 3-4 days from the onset - not 3-4 weeks as given in option 1 - hence it is a false statement.

Initial Secondary Syphilis lesions are discrete light red or pink, nonpruritic macules that are spread throughout the trunk and proximal extremities; these macules develop into papular lesions that are widely dispersed and commonly affect the palms and soles.

Non-centrally distributed rash AKA centrifugal rash (Rashes of the Palms and Soles)

questions.text: Cerebellar lesion cannot produce:

A cerebellar lesion can produce all of the given symptoms except Resting tremors.
