questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is prescribed phenytoin and valproate after being diagnosed with epilepsy. She experienced a generalised rash all over her body four weeks later, which eventually went away after she stopped using both medications. When she is given another chance to take phenytoin and valproate, how many weeks will pass before the rash reappears?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 1 day
 
  • The situation given in the question appears to be of a hypersensitivity to Phenytoin.
  • This manifests in 3- to 4-week intervals. 
  • When the medication is retested, the mediators are already created and released considerably more quickly, resulting in the rash developing much more quickly.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 419.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Sjogren's syndrome's is untrue?
questions.solution:
Due to a decrease in the serous component of saliva, Sjogren's syndrome patients have higher concentrations of sodium and IgA. (ductal secretions are unaltered). Due to the fact that phosphate is produced by the gland rather than a duct, the concentration is essentially the same.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2789, 2790.

questions.text: All of the following statements about the condition of the patient with splenomegaly, anaemia, and jaundice are true, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Low reticulocyte count
 
  • In cases of hemolytic anemia, increased reticulocytes are seen in the circulation.
  • This happens as a response to the increased lysis of erythrocytes; i.e. immature RBCs are released into the circulation from bone marrow.
  • Increased hemolysis lead to increased LDH and bilirubin formation, bilirubin is broken down to water soluble urobilinogen . Hemoglobin released binds to haptoglobin leading to decreased haptoglobin levels. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 637.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is best for determining whether an individual has intestinal malabsorption?
questions.solution:
• The D-Xylose absorption test, which examines Xylose absorption in the intestinal villi and can differentiate between Intestinal and Pancreatic malabsorption, is the most effective test for diagnosing Intestinal Malabsorption
 
  • Urinary D-xylose Test: The urinary D-xylose test for carbohydrate absorption provides a measure of proximal small-bowel absorptive function. d-Xylose, a pentose, is absorbed almost exclusively in the proximal small intestine and is excreted in the urine. The d-xylose test is usually performed by administering 25 g of d-xylose and collecting urine for 5 h. An abnormal test (excretion of <4.5 g) primarily reflects duodenal/jejunal mucosal disease.
 
  • For pancreatic malabsorption,we use the NBT-PABA and serum amylase assays.
  • Although, the gold standard for intestinal malabsorption is considered as faecal fat estimation, D-Xylose absorption is the best test.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2468.

questions.text: Choose the true diverticulum of esophagus.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Parabronchial diverticulum

All of the diverticula except the Parabronchial diverticula seen in the middle Esophagus are false diverticula.

* Esophageal diverticula are either:

  • True diverticula: Include all esophageal layers
  • False diverticula: Contain only mucosa and submucosa herniating through the muscular layer (e.g. Zenker's diverticulum)

Fig: Barium esophagram demonstrating a giant midesophageal diverticulum

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1029.

questions.text: Identify the region marked in the picture that represents zone 4 of retroperitoneal hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Marked region ‘A’ represents the zone 4 of retroperitoneal hemorrhage.
The retroperitoneum is usually divided into three parts based on site of injury. Some authors also describe a 4th zone, i.e. the portal and retro hepatic area.
Zone 1 (central) extends from the esophageal hiatus to the sacral promontory.
Zone 2 (lateral) extends from the lateral diaphragm to the iliac crest.
Zone 3 (pelvic) is confined to the retroperitoneal space of the pelvic bowl.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 382.

questions.text: The following is not a sign of respiratory insufficiency:
questions.solution:
All of the following are signs of Respiratory difficulty:
  1. Hypoxia
  2. Inspiratory Stridor
  3. Inability to speak.
 

Cases of Respiratory insufficiency must be tackled as an emergency situation, emergency airway access should be performed for relief.

questions.text: Identify the muscle splitting incision.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lanz incision

A Lanz incision is a commonly performed abdominal incision for open appendicectomy.

  • The Lanz incision is an oblique incision made along Langer's lines and this is a muscle splitting incision.
  • It is also known as the Rockey-Davis incision and it is essentially a modification of the traditional Gridiron incision (also known as McBurney's incision).It is a transverse incision centred over McBurney's point (two-thirds from the umbilicus to the ASIS).
  • The incision extends medially to the lateral border of the rectus abdominis and laterally the same distance. It is commonly completed or open appendicectomy and is considered to have a better cosmetic result compared to the Gridiron incision.
The Kocher incision is a subcostal incision on the right side of the abdomen used for open exposure of the gallbladder and biliary tree.
  • This incision is just inferior and parallel to the subcostal margin. Unlike the midline incision, it is not an avascular plane.
  • The incision extends through the anterior rectus fascia, rectus muscle, internal oblique, transverse abdominis, transversalis fascia, and peritoneum.


The Rutherford-Morrison is an extension of the gridiron incision that is commonly performed for transplant surgery.

  • The Rutherford-Morrison incision is commonly completed for renal transplants.
  • It may be used on the left or right-hand side. The incision begins ~2 cm above the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and extends obliquely down and medially through the skin and deeper tissue cutting them along the line of the skin incision.


The Pfannenstiel incision is a commonly used transverse incision to perform pelvic surgery. 

  • Pfannenstiel's incision refers to a low transverse incision (10-15 cm) that is 2-5 cm above the pubic symphysis.
  • It provides excellent access into the intra-pelvic cavity.


Fig: Abdominal Incisions

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 98.

questions.text: You have been assigned to suture the incision following a midline laparotomy. Appropriate length of suture material should be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 4x incision length

+ Jenkins Rule: 
It is a rule for the mass closure of the abdominal wound. It states that for a continuous suture, the length of the suture used should be at least four times the length of the wound with sutures 1cm apart and with 1cm bites of the wound edge.


Fig: Jenkin’s rule – the amount of the suture should be at least four times the length of the wound

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 109.

choices.text: Damage control surgery and mesh closure of abdomen

questions.text: A 30-year-old male who was injured in a car accident arrived at the trauma centre. His BP is 90/56 mm Hg, his pulse is 150/min, his oxygen saturation is 86%, and he has a Glasgow Coma Scale of 8. The patient had several wounds upon examination, and FAST shows haemorrhage in every quadrant. He underwent surgery, and the photos from the recovery are displayed here. Which of the following statements best sums up the two images?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Damage control surgery and mesh closure of abdomen
 
  • The images show an open abdomen with the use of a temporary abdominal closure (TAC) device, such as a vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) system.
  • This technique is often employed in damage control surgery, which involves controlling bleeding and contamination rapidly to stabilize the patient.
  • The TAC device helps prevent abdominal compartment syndrome and allows for subsequent definitive closure of the abdomen using a mesh.

Indications for temporary abdominal closure include:
  • Damage control (severe hemorrhage, hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis).
  • Abdominal compartment syndrome
  • Planned re-look laparotomy
  • Severe intra-abdominal sepsis
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 385.

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Laparoscopic port trocar
 
  • The instrument shown in the image is a laparoscopic port trocar.
  • A trocar is a sharp-pointed surgical instrument used to create access into body cavities during laparoscopic procedures.
  • It is inserted through a small incision in the abdominal wall, allowing the placement of laparoscopic instruments and camera for visualization.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 657.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male who arrived with rectal bleeding was found to have colon cancer. He had extensive right hemicolectomy. Below is a surgical tool that is being used. Name it -
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is used to perform Monopolar Cautery.

With the use of a specialised tool, electrosurgery uses high-frequency electrical current to cut, coagulate, desiccate, and fulgurate tissue.
It can be carried out using either monopolar or bipolar energy.

Reference: Cordero I. Electrosurgical units - how they work and how to use them safely. Community Eye Health. 2015;28(89):15-6. PMID: 26435589; PMCID: PMC4579996.

choices.text: After partial expansion of lungs and <50 mL output from drain for 2 consecutive days
After complete expansion of lungs and <30 mL output from drain for 2 consecutive days
After complete expansion of lungs and <100 mL output from drain for 24 hours

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man who is a known case of myasthenia gravis underwent VATS thymectomy for thymoma. Intraoperatively, the surgeon inadvertently damaged the pleura and therefore decided to insert a chest drain in the pleural cavity. Which among the following parameters will help the surgeon decide on chest drain removal?

1. After partial expansion of lungs and <50 mL output from drain for 2 consecutive days
2. After complete expansion of lungs and <30 mL output from drain for 2 consecutive days
3. After complete expansion of lungs and <100 mL output from drain for 24 hours
4. On 4th day, irrespective of the output from the drain and lung expansion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3)  After complete expansion of lungs and <100 mL output from drain for 24 hours

Among the given options the most appropriate answer is  After complete expansion of lungs and <100 mL output from drain for 24 hours.

+Criteria for Chest Tube removal:
  • Stable clinical condition
  • Wide-open lung in X-ray of the tube thoracostomy
  • Discharge of less than 200 cc in twenty-four hours
  • No air leak

Fig: Chest tube with Underwater seal Drainage

* [Extra Edge]: ICD removal

Chest tubes may be safely removed following demonstrated pleural space evacuation, on underwater seal, with <300 mL output over prior 24 hours.
  • It is done once chest X-ray confirms that lung gas has expanded properly, pleural fluid drain becomes serous and less than 25 mU day for 3 consecutive days, water column movement becomes less than 1 cm.
  • It is removed under all aseptic precaution; suture is removed; patient is asked to take deep inspiration; often outer end of the tube may be connected to low volume suction.
  • At the summit of deep inspiration, tube is pulled out; wound is cleaned quickly and if sealing suture is present it should be tied firmly; sealed plaster dressing is placed to avoid re-entry of air into the plural cavity.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1107.

questions.text: An unresponsive patient has been brought to you by the police. What will you do initially, precisely?
questions.solution:
Since the patient in the question is already identified as being unresponsive, we should go on to the next BLS phase, which is Checking for Pulse.

Steps of BLS:

  • Airway
  • Breathing
  • Send for AED
  • Circulation
  • Give rescue breaths 
  • Continue CPR





Reference: Adult BLS Algorithm for Healthcare Providers, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2262.

choices.text: Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
Insert a cannula and start IV fluids

questions.text: You are presented with a 45-year-old patient who is experiencing persistent, severe haemorrhage. The patient's hemodynamics are stable and they are awake. What will the first management action be?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
 
  • Any patient who has collapsed or likely to collapse should have their airway managed first as part of the ATLS strategy.
  • The airway is the most crucial system at risk in this patient and needs prompt care because the patient's hemodynamics are stable.
  • To reduce the danger of aspiration of blood, the patient should be placed in a recovery posture, or left lateral decubitus.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 391, 392.

questions.text: Select the most common symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease.
questions.solution:
Most common symptom of aortoiliac disease is gluteal claudication.
  • “The site of claudication is distal to the location of the occlusive lesion.
  • For example, buttock, hip, thigh, and calf discomfort occurs in patients with aortoiliac disease, whereas calf claudication develops in patients with femoral- popliteal disease.” “Aortoiliac disease (30 per cent of cases) may cause thigh or buttock claudication.
  • Buttock claudication in association with sexual impotence resulting from arterial insufficiency is eponymously called Leriche’s syndrome. It is very rare.”


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1000.

questions.text: What is the possible explanation for a bilirubin level of 40 mg/dL in a patient with obstructive jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Renal failure
 
  • All causes of cholestatic jaundice, such as malignant blockage and total CBD obstruction, can result in high jaundice, but concurrent renal failure causes bilirubin levels to rise over 30 mg/dL.
  • Conjugated bilirubin may be eliminated in urine and is soluble. However, this process is not present in renal failure, and the serum bilirubin can increase to extremely high levels.
 

* Audio Explanation: 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1377.

questions.text: Which of these is not seen in MEN-1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Posterior pituitary tumors

Posterior pituitary tumors are not seen in case of MEN-1 syndrome because in MEN disorders, only anterior pituitary tumours develop.
Since the posterior pituitary contains neural components, endocrine neoplasias cannot develop there.




Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 912.

questions.text: Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) cannot by itself diagnose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Follicular carcinoma of thyroid

FNAC is not enough to diagnose Follicular Carcinoma of Thyroid Gland:

Only a core tissue biopsy can show evidence of basement membrane and capsular invasion, which are crucial to distinguish between follicular adenomas and follicular carcinoma of the thyroid.

Simply observing atypical malignant cells in the fine needle aspirate material can detect papillary carcinomas, breast cancer, and lung cancer.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 858.

questions.text: Which of these scoring systems is used for research and monitoring and is useful in determining the degree of wound infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Southampton grading scale

* Audio Explanation:


Southampton grading scale and ASEPSIS wound score are used for research and monitoring and is useful in determining the degree of wound infection

+ The following options were given in the question:
  • Southampton grading is used for surgical site infections.
  • Glasgow score is a coma score to assess consciousness.
  • ASA classification is used to assess anaesthesia risk in a patient .
  • APGAR is a neonatal prognostic score.


Fig: The Southampton Wound Scoring System

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 27th Edition, Page No 48.

questions.text:
After receiving treatment for the infection following a laparotomy, a woman arrives with a ruptured abdomen. The doctor decides to suture again. What kind of suture material should be utilized out of the following?
1. 

2. 

3. 

4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 

The above Clinical Picture is of Acute Wound dehiscence or Brust Abdomen.

It is disruption of a laparotomy wound, occurring usually between 5th and 8th postoperative day.
At around 7–10 days postoperatively, leakage of clear or serosanguineous fluid from the wound is the first ominous sign of incipient dehiscence.


Fig: Abdominal wound dehiscence in a transverse incision with evisceration of bowel

* [Extra Edge]: Burst Abdomen

  • Usually sutures opposing the deep layers, i.e. peritoneum and rectus sheath tear through, causing burst abdomen-Acute wound failure.
  • It is a mechanical wound failure due to various factors causing separation of the closed abdominal wound often with evisceration of the contents.
  • Modified Smead-Jones closure mainly used to prevent burst abdomen-it is interrupted specialised suture used in the closure of abdomen as single layer excluding the skin. Number one polyethylene or PDS suture material is used. 
  • Nonabsorbable monofilament suture material is used for the closure even though evidence says that there is no difference between synthetic absorbable like polyglactic acid and nonabsorbable monofilament suture. Nonabsorbable suture causes prolonged wound pain but is preferred in risk category patients.
  • Suture bite interval should be 1 cm but not more; suture length and wound length ratio should be 4:1 or more but not less.

* Audio Explanation:

* [Extra Edge]: Management of Burst Abdomen
 
  • Primary deep fascial closure-deep tension/retention sutures
  • Delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or pack/opposite or Bogota bag 
  • Topical negative (vacuum) pressure closure
  • Delayed skin closure or skin graft over the dehiscence wound once it granulates well.
  • Component separation technique with primary fascial closure
  • Placing drain in subcutaneous plane
  • Suitable antibiotic therapy; fluid management
  • Prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome, hematoma or intra-abdominal abscess formation or sepsis
  • Blood or blood product transfusion; nutrition supplementation

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 732.

questions.text: Non-visualization of gallbladder in hepatic scintigraphy indicates which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Acute cholecystitis due to gallstones

Non-visualization of gallbladder in hepatic scintigraphy is suggestive of Acute cholecystitis.
 
  • Ultrasonography is the most useful radiologic test for diagnosing acute cholecystitis. It has a sensitivity and specificity of 95%. In addition to being a sensitive test for documenting the presence or absence of stones, it will show the thickening of the gallbladder wall and the pericholecystic fluid.
  • Focal tenderness over the gallbladder when compressed by the sonographic probe (sonographic Murphy’s sign) also is suggestive of acute cholecystitis. Biliary radionuclide scanning (HIDA scan) may be of help in the atypical case.
  • Lack of filling of the gallbladder after 4 hours indicates an obstructed cystic duct and, in the clinical setting of acute cholecystitis, is highly sensitive and specific for acute cholecystitis. A normal HIDA scan excludes acute cholecystitis.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1405.

questions.text:
An adnexal tumour is plaguing a 35-year-old woman. LDH was increased, CA199 was normal, CA125 was just slightly elevated. The gross and microscopic images of the tumour after it was removed are shown below. Which diagnosis is most likely?

1 .Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma
2. Dysgerminoma
3. Teratoma
4. Choriocarcinoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Dysgerminoma
 
  • LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) is an enzyme that can be elevated in certain tumors, including dysgerminoma.
  • CA-19-9 and CA-125 are tumor markers that are typically elevated in different types of ovarian tumors, but in this case, they are within the normal range or only slightly elevated, making dysgerminoma more likely.
  • Dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor that commonly occurs in young women and has specific histological features, as shown in the images.
* Tumor Markers:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1024.

questions.text: The stages of labour are depicted in the following graph. Which of the following claims about the graph C is true?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Secondary arrest after progression of labor


   



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 401, 434-437.

questions.text: Which of the following is carried out during the first trimester as a Down's syndrome screening test?
questions.solution:
Beta HCG and PAPP-A
 
Screening strategies for Down syndrome
First trimester screening (10 - 14 weeks):
• Maternal age 32%
• Nuchal translucency measurement (by ultrasound) 74%
• First trimester double test (PAPP-A, \(\beta\)-hCG) 63%
• First trimester combined test (nuchal translucency, PAPP-A, \(\beta\)-hCG) >86%
Second trimester screening (15 to 19 weeks):
• Maternal age 32%
• Second trimester double test (AFP, HCG) 60%
• Triple test (AFP, HCG, uE3) 68%
• Quadruple test (AFP, HCG, uE3, inhibin A) 79%
• Integrated test (first trimester: nuchal translucency, PAPP-A and \(\beta\)-hcG: second trimester: quadruple test) 95%
Prenatal diagnosis:
Amniocentesis (14-16 weeks) 100%
Chorionic villus sampling (10-12 weeks) 100%
FISH 100%



Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 335,336

questions.text: An operation was performed on a patient who had an adnexal mass, and the subsequent tumour was excised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Mature teratoma
 
  • The image shows hair with debacle material suggestive of a Dermoid cyst ( mature teratoma)
  • It is a type of germ cell tumor that is usually made up of several different types of tissue, such as hair, muscle, and bone.

MATURE CYSTIC TERATOMA (DERMOID CYSTS): 

• Most common germ cell neoplasm
• Well-differentiated derivations from at least two of the three germ cell layers
• Younger age group (mean patient age, 30 years)
• Asymptomatic
• Grow slowly
• Bilateral in about 10% of cases



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 445, 446.

questions.text: How much misoprostol should be taken orally to prevent postpartum bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. 600 micrograms> 1. 400 micrograms

Misoprostol is used for prevention of postpartum haemorrhage
Misoprostol is suitable for hemorrhage prophylaxis and is given orally as a single 400- or 600-μg dose

Recommended Dosages(Prevention of PPH)
600 microgram orally or sublingually when injectable conventional uterotonics are not available
2nd Dose - after 2h or 6h if marked shivering/pyrexia

Dosage for Treatment of established PPH
800 microgram

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 507.

questions.text: What is the postpartum haemorrhage treatment device known as a Bakri balloon's maximum capacity?
questions.solution:
Its maximum capacity is usually 500ml.

Bakri balloon is inserted into the uterine cavity and the balloon is inflated with normal saline (200–500 mL). It is kept for 4–6 hours. But maximum capacity is 500 ml.
It is successful in atonic PPH. This can avoid hysterectomy in 78% cases. It is considered the first line surgical intervention for most women with atonic PPH.

 




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 480, 482.

choices.text: Induce labor by artificial rupture of membranes
Sedate the patient by and give phenergan to decrease labor pains
Observe the patient and wait for increase in uterine contractions

questions.text: A primigravida who was 38 weeks pregnant arrived in the delivery room with little contractions and labour pains. The cervix is 50% effaced and 2 cm dilated on examination. The patient's blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg and heart rate is 86/min. What action is necessary now?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Observe the patient and wait for increase in uterine contractions
  • Inducing labor by artificial rupture of membranes (option 1) is not indicated at this point because the cervix is only 2 cm dilated and contractions are minimal.
  • Giving oxytocin to augment labor (option 2) is also not appropriate because labor has not progressed sufficiently.
  • Sedating the patient with phenergan (option 3) is unnecessary and may not be beneficial, as it does not address the underlying labor progression.


Labour is divided into three stages.
The first stage (stage of dilatation): From the onset of true labour until the cervix is fully dilated.
It is divided into two phases:

1. The latent phase:
- Starts from onset of labour until the cervix reaches 3 cm dilatation.
- Lasts between 3-8 hours, shorter in multiparous women.
- Contractions occurs at least twice every 10 minutes with each lasting > 20 seconds, not more than moderately strong and are quite well tolerated without analgesia.

2. The active phase:
From 3 cm-full cervical dilatation (10 cm), here the contractions becomes more frequent and stronger.
- Contractions occurs 3 times every 10 minutes, with each lasting > 40 seconds.
- The cervix should dilate at a rate of 1 cm/hour of faster.
Last between 2-6 hours.
- The duration of the 1st stage of labour in promipara patient range from 6-18 hours (average = 12 hours).
- In multiparous women about 2-10 hours (average 5 hours)



Reference: Williams Obstretics, 26th edition, Page no 424-429.

questions.text: Select the drug of choice for precocious puberty in girls.
questions.solution:
GnRH analogue
The objectives of treatment for children with central precocious puberty (CPP) are to avoid psychosocial problems caused by early pubertal development and to normalize adult height (AH). A long-acting GnRH analog is the treatment of choice for CPP.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 84.

questions.text: You were sent a young woman who has primary amenorrhea. Examination indicates no axillary hairs and typical breast development. An examination of the pelvis reveals a clitoromegaly and a normally formed vagina. The gonads can be seen in the inguinal area on ultrasonography. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome
Findings of clitoromegaly with no axillary hairs and typical breast development are suggestive of partial AIS.
 
  • A genetic condition where affected people have male chromosomes and male gonads with complete or partial feminization of the external genitals
  • An inherited X-linked recessive disease with a mutation in the Androgen Receptor (AR) gene resulting in:
    - Functioning Y sex chromosome
    - Abnormally on X sex chromosome
  • Types
    - CAIS (completely insensitive to AR gene)
        • External female genitalia
        • Lacking female internal organs
    - PAIS (partially sensitive-varying degrees)
        • External genitalia apperance on a spectrum (male to female)
    - MAIS (mildly sensitive, rare)
        • Impaired sperm development and/or impaired masculinization
  • Also called Testicular Feminization





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 109, 113.

choices.text: Pap smear should be repeated yearly in women of reproductive age group
HPV test should be done five yearly in women between age of 30 to 49 years
Visual inspection with acetic acid is more reliable at older age as it becomes easier to identify the transformation zone with age
Pap smear can be repeated less frequently if it comes out negative for 3 consecutive years

questions.text: Choose the statement that is not true about cervical cancer screening guidelines according to WHO.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Pap smear should be repeated yearly in women of reproductive age group
Pap smear is done every 3 yearly. 
Screening Methods for Cervical Cancer: 
 
Population Recommended screening method Comments
Women younger than 21 years No screening -
Women 21 to 29 years of age Cytology alone every three years -
Women 30 to 65 years of age HPV and cytology contesting (preferred) every five years Screening by HPV testing alone is not recommended
-
Women older than 65 years No screening is necessary after adequate negative prior screening results Women with a history of CN 2, CIN 3, or adenocarcinoma in situ should continue routine age-based screening for at least 20 years
Women who have had a total hysterectomy No screening is necessary Applies to women without a cervix and without a history of CIN 2, CIN3, adenocarcinoma in situ, or cancer in the past 20 years
Women vaccinated against HPV Follow age-specific recommendations (same as unvaccinated women) -



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 411, 412.

choices.text: Ultrasound should be done in all cases
If the patient has an IUCD in-situ, it doesn’t need to be removed
Can only be done up to 72 days
Only a person certified under MTP act can perform medical termination of pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following statements about medical abortion is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Only a person certified under MTP act can perform medical termination of pregnancy

Criteria for MTP: 

1. Opinion of one RMP for termination of pregnancy up to 20 weeks.
2. Opinion of 2 RMPs for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks.
3. Pregnancy can be terminated up to 24 weeks, only in cases of survivors of rape and severe fetal anomalies which are incompatible with life.
4. In case of failure of contraceptive in a women of her partner, MTP can be done only up to 20 weeks.
5. MTP can be done even after 24 weeks in case of substantial foetal abnormalities diagnosed by a Medical Board.
6. Ultrasound is not needed in all cases.
7.The IUCD should be removed before performing a medical abortion.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 202, 203.

choices.text: Alert and action lines are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Partograph recording should be started at a cervical dilation of 10 cm
Send the patient to first referral unit if the labor progression line crosses the alert line

questions.text: The partograph illustrates the numerous time-related stages of work. Every partograph fact is accurate, with the exception of which one:
questions.solution:
• Partograph recording begins at end of latent phase and when active phase begins which is at cervical dilation of 4 or 5 cm. 
  • Partograph is a composite graphical record of key data (maternal and fetal) during labor, entered against time on a single sheet of paper.
  • In cervicograph (Philpott & Caste 1972), the alert line starts at 4 cm (Now 5 cm according to WHO Labour care guide) of cervical dilatation and ends at 10 cm dilatation (at the rate of 1 cm/hr).
  • The action line is drawn 4 hours to the right and parallel to the alert line. In a normal labor, the cervicograph (cervical dilatation) should be either on the alert line or to the left of it.
  • When it falls on Zone 2, it is abnormal and need to be critically assessed. When it falls in Zone 3 case should be reassessed by a senior person. Decision is to be made either for termination of labor (cesarean section) or for augmentation of labor (amniotomy and or oxytocin).
Hence, statement (3) is incorrect.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 606, 607.

questions.text: Which one of the following accurately describes a typical oral glucose tolerance test?
questions.solution: Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 1079

questions.solution:
• Self-mutilation behaviour is frequently observed in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is brought on by a lack of HGPRT.
  • Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome : HPRT deficiency is a rare X-linked impairment of purine metabolism.

questions.text: A newborn was diagnosed with hepatomegaly during a routine checkup soon after birth. The remainder of the exam was largely ordinary. Investigations revealed that anti-HCMV antibodies were present. What long-term consequences could the youngster face?
questions.solution:
• Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) antibodies that are positive at birth are indicative of congenital infection with CMV that is not symptomatic.
  • The risk of mental retardation is higher in children who have symptoms of CMV infection, while the chance of sensorineural hearing loss is higher in asymptomatic children—up to 7%.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 264,265

questions.text: The birth defect exhibited in the infant below was likely caused due to the use of which of the following medications during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The cleft lip given in the image above is typical of Isotretinoin's teratogenic effects.This medication should never be taken in a female of reproductive age without first ruling out pregnancy as it is often used to treat acne. Isotretinoin should be stopped atleast/minimum 1 month before pregnancy.


Retinoid Syndrome in Foetuses

Retinoids, which are synthetic vitamin A derivatives, if used by pregnant women and cause a distinctive pattern of birth abnormalities.

  • Craniofacial abnormalities: These may include small or malformed ears, cleft palate(as given , or facial asymmetry.
  • Central nervous system defects: Hydrocephalus or microcephaly
  • Cardiac abnormalities:  Ventricular septal defects/transposition of the great arteries 
  • Visual system abnormalities:  small or absent eyes (microphthalmia), cataracts, or optic nerve abnormalities.

Other options
Ferrous Sulphate(iron) and Folate are not teratogenic, infact given in pregnancy as supplements to reduce anemia/neural tube defect risk. Metaclopramide is non-teratogenic and a safe anti-emetic in pregnancy. 


Reference- Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology 14th Edition Page no 527

questions.text: A humanized monoclonal antibody is called palivizumab. Which of the ensuing circumstances has it been authorised for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Respiratory syncytial virus
 
  • Infections with the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) can be prevented and treated using the monoclonal antibody palivizumab.
  • It is advised for infants who are at high risk due to preterm or other health issues, such as congenital heart disease.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 802.

questions.text: Young child was brought to the OPD with difficulty in walking. Below is the image of his legs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows calf pseudohypertrophy, an abnormal expansion of the calves by fibrofatty proliferation
  • It is a hallmark of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the most prevalent kind of muscular dystrophy.

choices.text: Refer to higher center with mother giving frequent sips of water
Immediately admit the child, give IV fluids and then refer to higher center
Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center in an ambulance with sips of ORS along the way

questions.text: A one-month-old boy who had been suffering of a fever for two days was brought to the subcenter by his mother. The child weighs 2 kilograms. Upon examination, it was discovered that the youngster was drowsy,felt very hot, that a skin pinch had returned very slowly, oral mucosa was dry, and the eyes were sunken. His forehead had ten pustules. What actions should be taken at the subcenter?
questions.solution:
The child must be given the first dose of antibiotics and referred to a higher center.(with sips of ORS)

The patient here has multiple signs of possible serious bacterial infection/very severe disease - (drowsy child/multiple pustules/felt hot suggesting high grade fever). Hence, According to IMNCI child should immediately referred after first dose of IV antibiotic. Since child also has severe dehydration - he should be ensured to have ORS on the way. 

Other options
 
  • Option 1 - Patient should be referred after giving the first dose of IV antibiotic, not without giving the first dose of IV Antibiotic and with ORS on the way - not water. 
  • Option 2 - Child does have severe dehydration(sunken eyes/drowsy child , delyed skin pinch) - however - According to IMNCI - if the child has severe dehydration with other signs of very severe disease/severe classification - child should be referred with ORS on the way rather than giving IV fluids at the subcentre.  See the image from IMNCI given below. 

 
  • Option 4 - Child has signs of severe bacterial disease - needs t be admitted and hence cannot be sent back home


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 289-292

questions.text:
A newborn who was 6 days old and 2800 gm at birth was brought in with complaints of fever, poor feeding, and ineffective activity. Both vomiting and diarrhea are absent. The child has a 39°C axillary temperature, sunken eyes, a depressed fontanelle, decreased urine output, and decreased skin turgor. Her mother also has a history of producing less milk and giving top feeds.
What is the likely cause for the above?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Neonatal sepsis
 
A LBW newborn, with poor breast feeding history and fever without the presence of diarrhoea or vomiting points towards late onset Neonatal sepsis.

Some points about Neonatal sepsis
  • Causative organism – klebisiella > staph aureus
  • 2nd most common cause of neonatal mortality after prematurity.
  • Diagnosis is made by presence of clinical features of sepsis along with bacteremia in 1st month of life.
  • Sepsis occouring within 72 hours of birth is transmitted from the mother’s birth canal during birth and leads to early onset pneumonia.
  • Late onset sepsis is defined as onset 72 hours after birth. It is hospital acquired due to negligence in maintaining cleanliness. Seen more frequently in LBW and preterm babies or those who are not breastfed. It mostly manifests as Septicemia or meningitis.
  • Treatment should be started immediately after taking blood samples for culture and testing. A combination of Ampicillin (gram+) + Amikacin (gram-) is given.
  • Other antibiotics like cephalosporins, cloxacillin and vancomycin are added if no response is observed.   

  Sepsis screen : 5 components are included
 




Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 160-162

questions.text: A neonate who had hypoplasia in all of his limbs and cicatrizing skin lesions all over his body presents to you. Brain MRI results showed generalised cerebral atrophy. Which of these has the highest likelihood of being positive?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option (3) Anti-VZV antibody

Congenital varicella infection should be suspected based on the clinical picture given in the question-  cicatrizing skin lesions and presence of limb hypoplasia along with cerebral atrophy. This infection can be identified using anti-VZV(Varicella zoster virus) antibodies.

Other options

Option 1 - Anti- HCMV would be positive in congenital CMV infection. Congenital CMV infection presents with jaundice, Hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rash along with chorioretinitis, microcephaly and periventricular calcifications.
Option 2 - Congenital Toxoplasmosis has chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus and diffuse calcification
Option 4 - Congenital Rubella has a triad of PDA/Sensory neural hearing loss and cataract. 
 


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 210,211

questions.text: What degree of temperature should be provided for newborns in the delivery room (delivery room temperature)?
questions.solution:
• Each birth and resuscitation room's ventilation system must be built to regulate the surrounding temperature between 25 and 28 degrees Celsius during delivery, resuscitation, and stabilization of a baby.
  • A delivery room temperature of 25 to 28 degrees Celsius is advised by the WHO - it provides an optimal temperature for resuscitation, temperature of 37 C is very high and would instead result in hyperthermia for neonate. 
     

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 134

choices.text: Square root of height in feet by weight in grams
Weight in grams by cube of height in centimetres multiplied by 100
Mid-upper arm circumference to head circumference ratio

questions.text: What is Ponderal index?
questions.solution:
• Ponderal Index is calculated by first multiplying the weight (in grams) by 100, then divide by the cube of the length in cm.
  • Ponderal Index is more than 2 in Symmetric IUGR, Ponderal index is less than 2 in asymmetric IUGR. 


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21st Page No 1048

questions.text: What is the ideal route of drug delivery in neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
• For medications, the umbilical vein is used, for the drug to reach the foetus.
  • Since veins in the scalp or extremities are difficult to access during resuscitation, the umbilical vein is the preferred route.

No intracardiac injection is recommended.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 133

choices.text: Observe only, as it is likely physiological jaundice
Liver function tests and liver biopsy to evaluate for cholestasis

questions.text: A neonate develops jaundice on the first day of life. The mother’s blood group is O negative. What is the most appropriate management for this baby?
questions.solution:
• In term newborns, jaundice that appears after 24 hours or doesnt last longer than 14 days is referred to as physiological jaundice.
  • However in the given question - the child develops jaundice on the first day of life itself suggesting jaundice is pathological in nature.
  • The most common cause of jaundice on the first day of life are hemolytic diseases or congenital infections
  • Considering the mother's blood group is O negative - its likely child might have Rh isoimmunisation/ABO incompatibility leading to jaundice and hence, phototherapy is required for the treatment of jaundice.

Other options

Option 1 - Physiological jaundice does not appear on day 1. It usually starts after 24 hours, peaks around day 5, and resolves within 2 weeks in term infants. Jaundice on day 1 is pathological. 

Option 2 - Double Volume Exchange transfusion i.e DVET (not partial exchange) is used in cases of severe hyperbilirubinemia not responsive to phototherapy, or when bilirubin is very high (more than DVET Cutoff) at presentation. In a newborn with early hemolysis, the first-line treatment is phototherapy, not exchange transfusion. 

Option 3 - Cholestasis tends to present later, usually after the first 2 weeks of life, with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (with child having high coloured urine and pale stools). On day 1, with an O negative mother, the clinical picture is of hemolysis, not cholestasis.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 169-172

choices.text: Inj. betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 12 hours apart
Inj. betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 24 hours apart
Inj. dexamethasone 6 mg for 4 doses 24 hours apart
Inj. dexamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 12 hours apart

questions.text: Select the recommended dose of steroids for attaining fetal lung maturity.
questions.solution:
Inj Betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 24 hours apart must be delivered to achieve lung maturity.

Benefits:

  • 50% reduction in the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome
  • 50% reduction in the Incidence of intraventricular haemorrhage (IVH)
  • 40% reduction in mortality
Steroid dosage Memorizing Trick-
Dexamethasone- Dexa similar to Hexa- 6- 6 mg every 12 hours 4 injections
Betamethasone- B- 2nd letter of albhabet- 2 dosage twice the dose of Dexa and gap- 12 mg 2 injections 24 hours apart


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 166

questions.text: Select the most likely cause of the abnormality seen in the wrist X-ray from a 12 years old boy as shown below.
questions.solution:
• The radiological image above shows cupping and fraying of the metaphyses, typically seen in rickets.
  • In active rickets there is thickening and widening of the growth plate, cupping of the metaphysis and, sometimes, bowing of the diaphysis.
  • The metaphysis may remain abnormally wide even after healing has occurred



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 310,311

questions.text: A patient is sent to the trauma centre after suffering a roadside injury. His left hip is quite painful, and upon inspection, it is incredibly tender and has a limited range of motion. In the position shown below, the patient is lying down. What kind of malformation is there in the patient?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows flexion, abduction and external rotation of left lower limb with limb lengthening seen in anterior dislocation of hip. 
  • Posterior dislocation- flexion, adduction and internal rotation with knee resting on  opposite limb and limb shortening. 
  • Remember- Most common type of hip dislocation is posterior.  
Memorizing Trick- 
Anterior Dislocation- FABER- Flexion ABduction External Rotation 
Posterior Dislocation- FADIR- Flexion ADduction Internal Rotation 



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 131

questions.text: A 12-year-old child complained of right hip pain. Below is a pelvic X-ray that was obtained. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
• The given pelvic radiograph shows a fracture of right femoral neck in a 12 year old boy, which will most likely be seen in option C- Osteogenesis Imperfecta. 
  • The X-ray shows  fractures in the femur and pelvis, which is a common feature of Osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • The fractures can occur spontaneously or with minimal trauma.


Other options:-
Osteoporosis unlikely to occur in 12 year old child and can't be determined on x ray 
Osteopetrosis will have bone with in bone appearance
Osteopoikilocytosis- multiple opacities scattered in metaphyseal region


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 316

questions.text: A young person arrives with a history of right hip pain and walking issues. Hip X-rays were taken as shown in the image. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Osteopetrosis, also known as Albers-Schönberg disease or marble bone disease, is an uncommon hereditary disorder that results from defective osteoclasts.
  • Bones become sclerotic and thick, but their abnormal structure actually causes them to be weak and brittle.
  • The given pelvic radiograph demonstrates bone within bone sign of osteopetrosis. 


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 317

questions.text: The patient in the X-ray below is 16 years old. What pathology is most likely to be present?

In this X-ray of the humerus head, we can see a faint patch loss of density and a sequestrum within the bone. This along with the young age, is suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: As may be seen in the Knee X-ray below, an athlete has a fracture. How will you treat this fracture?
questions.solution:
• The given radiograph shows displaced patellar fracture which is managed by tension wire banding.
  • It works on the principle of converting distraction force from pull of quadriceps muscle into tension force. 
  • Tension wire banding is also performed for displaced olecranon fractures against distraction pull of triceps muscle. 
  • Undisplaced fractures of patella are managed conservatively by cylindrical cast. 
     
Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 148

questions.text: Which of these is likely to cause the following malformation as seen in the image?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows bilateral cubitus varus deformity ( Gunstock deformity ) seen in supracondylar fracture of humerus. 
  • Supracondylar fractures are common in children and typically occur when a child falls on an outstretched hand with an extended elbow

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 102

questions.text: Which of the following promotes the production of calluses?
questions.solution:
• Small amount of motion ( micromovements ) and weight bearing at the fracture causes a soft callus to form leading on to secondary bone formation. It encourages vascular proliferation.
  • Depending on the stability of fixation and the underlying fracture pattern, weight bearing is started as early as possible to 'stimulate' fracture healing.
  • Some fixators incorporate a telescopic unit that allows 'dynamization'; this will convert the forces of weight-bearing into axial micro movement at the fracture site, thus promoting callus formation and accelerating bone union. 
  • Rigid immobilization, compression plating, and intraosseous nailing are techniques used to stabilize the broken bone ends and prevent excessive movement. While they are important for proper bone alignment and stability, they do not directly promote the formation of callus.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 11,12,49

questions.text: The following tool is utilized for indirect ophthalmoscopy and is depicted in the figure. What magnification should be used along with it to see the retina?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is 2: +20D.

The instrument shown in the image is used for indirect ophthalmoscopy.
The principle of this procedure is to make the eye highly myopic. Light is transmitted from the headset to the fundus through a condensing lens held at the focal point of the eye, providing an inverted image that is observed through a stereoscopic viewing system.
A convex lens is used, commonly +20D.
The image formed is real, inverted, and magnified.
It is used for assessing and managing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions.





Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 113, 548.

questions.text:
Nowadays, lasers are used to conduct a range of eye procedures, including cataract surgeries, with minimal incisions, fewer postoperative problems, and quicker recovery times. What is the laser's pulse duration, as depicted below, used for cataract surgery?

1. 10-15 seconds
2. 10-12 seconds
3. 10-9 seconds
4. 10-6 seconds
questions.solution:
The image shown here shows Femtosecond laser. Femtosecond laser-assisted surgery (FLACS) represents a relatively new technology that some surgeons have adopted for cataract extraction. Pulse frequency of FLACS is 10^-15.

Advantages of Femtosecond laser:

  • Femtosecond lasers have a unique ability to create discrete photodisruption of tissue with minimal collateral effects.
  • This enables very precise cutting in ocular tissues, including the cornea, the lens capsule, and the crystalline lens.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 381, 382.

choices.text: Topical natamycin only, no need to drain the hypopyon

questions.text: Following an eye stick injury, a farmer visited the ophthalmological emergency department with blurred vision, redness, tearing, photophobia, pain, and a feeling of a foreign body. A corneal ulcer with redness and fuzzy edges is discovered during examination. The image below depicts an eye. How are you going to handle this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case is of a Fungal Corneal Ulcer with immobile hypopyon.
  • Topical Natamycin is effective against yeasts and has a broad spectrum of activity against filamentous organisms.
  • There is no need to drain the hypopyon as white blood cells present in a hypopyon provide protection against an invading infection, thus one should never try to drain it.
  • However, a persistent hypopyon can lead to anterior synechiae and close-angle glaucoma.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 228, 229.

questions.text: Which area of the eye makes up the most of the eye's refractive power?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Anterior surface of cornea
 
  • The anterior surface of the cornea has an essentially spherical shape with a typical 8 mm radius of curvature. About two thirds of the eye's refractive power comes from this area.
  • Approximately two-thirds of refraction occurs at the air–tear–corneal interface, which generally parallels the anterior surface of the cornea.
  • Since the move from the air into the cornea is where the light undergoes the most change in index of refraction, the majority of that refraction in the eye occurs there.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 54, 77.

questions.text: What is the typical rabbit weight used in ophthalmology research?
questions.solution:
The usual weight of a rabbit used in an ophthalmological experiment is around 1.5 to 2.5 kgs.
  • The rabbits weigh about 1.8-2.2 kg, male, and have no anterior segment lesions in both eyes. The right eyes were selected in the research group while the left eyes were taken as normal control group.
  • After performing vitrectomy, the research eyes of rabbits were divided into three groups: Group A, injection with 24 mg/mL cross-linked sodium hyaluronate gel; Group B, injection with 40 mg/mL cross-linked sodium hyaluronate gel; Group C, injection with steriled 0.9% saline, mean normal control.


Reference: Gong, Yan et al. “Effect on rabbits' intraocular structure by cross-linked hyaluronic formations as vitreous substitute.” International journal of ophthalmology vol. 13,10 1531-1537. 18 Oct. 2020, doi:10.18240/ijo.2020.10.04

questions.text: A 26-year-old man who had suddenly lost vision in his left eye came to the emergency room. The fluorescein angiography produced the image that is displayed below. Below is an illustration of the optical coherence tomography image. Which layers of the retina experience fluid buildup?
questions.solution:
• The arrow in the given picture points towards Retinal Pigment epithelium.
  • The OCT and FFA in this case point to Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR), which is characterised by fluid buildup in the subretinal space and separation of retinal pigment epithelium from the neurosensory retina.


FFA shows the characteristic Mushroom/ Umbrella pattern or Smoke stack appearance.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 607-609.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent conditions does the image in question represent?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

The given case appears to be of Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia(INO), which is a  conjugate lateral gaze abnormality that causes adduction dysfunction in the afflicted eye.
  • INO occurs due to injury to the Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF), between the abducens nucleus and the contralateral medial rectus subnucleus of the oculomotor nerve, interrupts transmission of neural impulses to the ipsilateral medial rectus muscle 
  • The afflicted eye does not adduct when an attempt is made to stare contralaterally (relative to the affected eye). However, there is nystagmus as the contralateral eye abducts.
Additionally, horizontal diplopia is brought on by the eyes' divergence.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 927, 928.

choices.text: Diminution of field vision to 10° or less in better eye
Inability of a person to count fingers from a distance of 3 meters or 10 feet
Vision 3/60 or less with the best possible spectacle correction in the better eye
Vision 4/60 or less with the best possible spectacle correction in the better eye

questions.text: Which of these does the NPCB not consider to be a proper definition of blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Vision 4/60 or less with the best possible spectacle correction in the better eye

Definition of Blindness as per NPCB (2017):
 
  1. Presenting distance visual acuity less than 3/60 (20/400) [Snellen’s]/ counting fingers at a distance of 3 metres in the better eye (OR)
  2. Limitation of field of vision to be less than 10 degree from centre of fixation.

Other definitions of Blindness:
 
  • Economic blindness: VA <6/60 to 3/60 in better eye.
  • Social blindness: VA <3/60 to 1/60 in better eye.
  • Legal/Manifest blindness: VA <1/60 to Perception of light (PL) in better eye.
  • Total/Absolute blindness: No PL (PL negative)


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 495, 496.

questions.text: An accident occurred to a construction worker, who then went to the trauma centre after a large concrete block fell on his face. He had significant laryngeal and maxillofacial injuries, it was discovered. He was unable to open his mouth, and upon investigation, it was discovered that both his oropharynx and nasopharynx had obstructions and many fractures. The following action was taken for him in order to keep a patent airway. Which of the following choices accurately defines the procedure?
questions.solution:
• In the given image Cricothyroidotomy is being performed.
  • A cricothyrotomy (also known as a cricothyroidotomy) is an incision made through the skin and cricothyroid membrane to create a patent airway in certain life-threatening circumstances, such as when a foreign body is blocking the airway, when angioedema is present, or when there has been significant facial trauma.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1406-1408.

questions.text: What level of hearing loss qualifies as Profound hearing loss, as defined by the WHO?
questions.solution:
#controversial 

WHO classification started in 1980 and has been revised in 1991 and now in 2021. 
According to the most recent classification, Profound hearing loss is >81dB. (However, earlier - it was >91dB)



NOTE: In some editions of Dhingra - WHO Classification mentions >91dB as profound loss- however - that is incorrectly given in the textbook - please check the actual WHO reference given below. 

Reference: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240021570

questions.text: Postherpetic neuralgia is classified as pain lasting for more than:
questions.solution:
4 Weeks 

Post-herpetic neuralgia (PHN), which is defined as considerable pain or dysesthesia present 3 months or more after HZ, is the most typical side effect of HZ. 

It is the best answer since there are several criteria for defining PHN, but none of them result in a period of less than four weeks.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 220.

questions.text: A female patient, age 24, has patchy baldness in the right temporal and occipital region. Upon examination, many little broken hairs and non-scarring alopecia were discovered. Scalp scrapings revealed peri-follicular bleeding, minor lymphocytic infiltration, and moderate inflammation. Which diagnosis is the most likely?
questions.solution:
• Trichotillomania (TTM), commonly referred to as the "hair pulling disorder," is an impulse control condition that is characterized by a persistent urge that causes hair pulling.
  • This happens to the point that the patient exhibits alopecia.
  • Hair pulling may occur at any site, although the head, pubic region and the area around the eyes are the most common.
  • Perifollicular hemorrhages could be seen on dermoscopy. 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 86.17

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with uncomfortable blisters over her vaginal and oral mucosa. She described the prior occurrences of corresponding lesions. On histology, a biopsy taken from the lesion revealed a suprabasal split. Intercellular IgG deposits were discovered using immunofluorescence microscopy, as seen below. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• The figure shows a direct immunofluorescence image revealing fishnet pattern with intercellular deposition of IgG against Desmoglein 1 & 3, classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • The clinico-immunofluorescence co-relation in the above patient confirms the diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris.


AIBD- Autoimmune Blistering Disorder
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.8

questions.text: Warts on the penis of a sexually active male were discovered, as seen below. Which of these HPV strains is mostly involved in these lesions?
questions.solution:
The picture suggests it to be a case of Anogenital warts on penis, which are caused by low-risk HPV viruses
i.e. HPV- 6 and 11.

questions.text: A 18-year-old boy came with a progressively worsening annular plaque which has central scarring on his head and neck region. Which diagnosis is most likely amongst these?
questions.solution:
• In Lupus vulgaris, an annular plaque with a central scar is characteristic.
  • Central scarring is never seen in the annular plaque-like Tinea cruris lesions, despite the fact that Tinea cruris is significantly more prevalent.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 27.21

questions.text: A cholecystectomy under general anaesthesia was arranged for a 40-year-old habitual smoker. He had anaesthetic induction with propofol and vecuronium, and isoflurane was administered to maintain the anaesthesia. The following capnograph plot was seen during the surgery. What might be the reason?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2: Entry into the right-sided bronchus
 
  • The capnograph plot shows a sudden drop in the end-tidal carbon dioxide (ETCO2) level, indicating a change in the ventilation pattern.
  • Entry into the right-sided bronchus during intubation can lead to selective intubation of the right lung, resulting in ventilation of only one lung.
  • This causes a decrease in the exhaled CO2 levels and a characteristic capnograph pattern.
  • The correct placement of the endotracheal tube should be confirmed by auscultation, chest rise, and bilateral breath sounds to ensure proper ventilation.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1397, 1398.
Gandhi, S K et al. “Capnography for detection of endobronchial migration of an endotracheal tube.” Journal of clinical monitoring vol. 7,1 (1991): 35-8. doi:10.1007/BF01617896

choices.text: A slight pressure may be applied at the cricoid cartilage
The laryngoscope is held in the left hand and introduced from the right side of the patient
After insertion of the laryngoscope, it is levered on the upper incisor to pull up the tongue and visualize the vocal cords

questions.text: All of these are true for laryngoscopy and intubation procedure, except which one:
questions.solution:
Option (4) is incorrect.

It's crucial to apply the laryngoscope's lifting pressure by
pushing the instrument away from you (target for where the wall facing you meets the ceiling),
as opposed to rocking or levering the handle backward
(risks damaging the patients' lips, gums, or teeth and
often results in an inferior view).


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1393-1396.

questions.text: What is the ratio of breaths to chest compressions when performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation alone in an adult?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. 30:2

Whether there are one or two rescuers, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breath for all persons is 30:2, i.e. 30 chest compressions for 2 breathing pauses, if no advanced airway is placed.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2261.
Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm, American Heart association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: Why is 100% oxygen given when nitrous oxide is stopped upon awakening from anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diffusion hypoxia

  • The procedure is done to prevent diffusion hypoxia.
  • The O2 and CO2 in the alveolus are temporarily diluted by N2O gas while the patient is recovering from the anesthesia because significant amounts of this gas pass from the blood into the alveolus (down its concentration gradient).
  • Hypoxia could result momentarily as a result of this decreasing oxygen partial pressure.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: A surgeon chooses to use epidural anaesthetic during a patient's procedure. Adrenaline and 3% Xylocaine are combined to administer epidural anaesthesia. After three minutes of injection, the patient experiences hypotension without warning. What causes this to happen most frequently?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Penetration into the subarachnoid space
 
  • Shortly after the drug enters the subarachnoid space, cardiovascular symptoms like hypotension arise suggesting the drug has been injected into the subarachnoid space which causes symtoms in few minutes. 
  • Vasovagal shock occurs im­mediately, i.e. even before the needle for epidural anaesthesia is injected.
 

Cardiovascular Complications of Central Blockade:

  • Hypotension (most common)
  • Bradycardia
  • Reflex tachycardia
  • Respiratory depression
  • Vasovagal effect
  • Systemic toxicity


Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 967.
Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 1047, 1715.

choices.text: Flail chest due to fracture of ribs 5, 6, 7 & 8

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was injured in a bike accident is brought to the emergency room complaining of coughing, dyspnea, and chest pain. At the time of evaluation, the patient's blood pressure was 130/80 mm Hg, his heart rate was 88 beats per minute, and his respiration rate was 22 beats per minute. On auscultation, there was less air entry and no breath sounds on one side. An oximeter reading of 98% indicates saturation. Below is an X-ray of the chest. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In the image above, we can see Hyperlucent left lung field with collapsed lung near the left heart border.

  • Pneumothorax is suspected because the surrounding hemithorax is found to be more translucent than usual with absence of broncho-vascular markings.
  • The central, non deviated location of the trachea is another indication that there is a pneumothorax with collapse.
  • When air leaves from the lung, it collapses. The area between the lung and the chest wall that is external to the lung is then filled with air.
  • The diagnosis is made by physical examination showing an enlarged hemithorax with no breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 373, 374.

questions.text:
An earthquake wrecked the home of an elderly woman 3 weeks ago. She then arrived to your office and spoke of feeling anxious, depressed, sad, sleep deprived, angry, and frustrated since then. Take into account the following claims:
a. The lady is suffering from acute stress disorder
b. The defense mechanism involved is projection
c. The therapy of choice in this situation is risperidone
d. She needs a referral to a psychiatrist for psychotherapy

Which of the following statements are true?
questions.solution:
• The elderly lady in the above scenario is suffering from Acute Stress Disorder.
  • She needs a psychotherapy session with a psychiatrist.


Acute Stress Disorder
 

  • Acute stress disorder is a common occurrence that starts after a traumatic incident. It occurs for a duration of >48 hours to less than 1 month. Often it subsides within a few days.
  • Projection is not used as a defensive strategy. After a traumatic event, psychological treatment can help with the acute stress reaction.
  • As a result, referral to a psychiatrist is more crucial than antipsychotic medications like risperidone. 
  • Preferred drug in Acute stress disorder is SSRI rather than antipsychotic.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 442, 445.

questions.text:
A male 22-year-old complains to you in your office about frequently checking doors even though they are locked. He is troubled by this reality. His obsessive-compulsive condition is subsequently identified. Take into account the following claims:
a.  Sublimation - the defense mechanisms involved
b. SSRIs are the drug of choice
c. Risperidone may be used in SSRI-resistant cases to augment the response
d. Systemic desensitization is the psychotherapy of choice

Which of the above are correct statements?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2: b & c
The given clinical scenario describes a condition called OCD.

Important points about OCD.
  • The common symptoms seen in OCD are Contamination (most common) > Pathological doubt > Intrusive thoughts > Symmetry
  • Defense Mechanisms in OCD – Displacement, Undoing, Reaction formation, Inhibition, Isolation of affect
  • Drug of choice - SSRI. Atypical antipsychotics (like risperidone) can be given in resistant cases
  • Psychotherapy of Choice -  Exposure and Response prevention which is a form of CBT.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 424-426.

choices.text: Physiological needs - Safety - Belonging - Self-esteem - Self- actualization

questions.text: Which of these represents the true hierarchy of needs according to Maslow?
questions.solution:
Correct sequence according to Maslow’s hierarchy is : Physiological needs - Safety - Belonging - Self-esteem - Self­ actualization.





Reference: Kenrick, Douglas T et al. “Renovating the Pyramid of Needs: Contemporary Extensions Built Upon Ancient Foundations.” Perspectives on psychological science : a journal of the Association for Psychological Science vol. 5,3 (2010): 292-314. doi:10.1177/1745691610369469
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 181.

questions.text: The court has referred someone to you. Between the results of the examination and the history, you discover a discrepancy. Which of these conditions in this circumstance should you be mindful of?
questions.solution:
• Malingering is the practise of fabricating or exaggerating the signs of mental or physical disorders for a number of "secondary gain" objectives, such as monetary gain (often associated with fraud), evading school, work, or military service, obtaining drugs, obtaining lighter sentences for crimes, or simply to garner sympathy or attention
  • Factitious disorder, is a condition where an individual intentionally produces or feigns physical or psychological symptoms for no apparent external gain.
  • Somatization syndrome, is a condition where an individual experiences multiple, recurring physical symptoms that have no apparent medical cause
  • Dissociative fugue, is a condition where an individual experiences a sudden, unexpected episode of amnesia and may wander away from their home or place of work


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 470, 474, 476.

questions.text: Polysomnography contains all of the following tests except:
questions.solution:
• The PSG monitors many body functions, including ECG, EMG, EOG, EEG. Depending upon the clinical scenario other functions such as sPO2/SaO2, esophageal pH too can be measured. 
  • However, pCO2 measurement would require an invasive ABG (causing pain) resulting in disruption of sleep and is not performed.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2206, 2207.
